text: hey everybody thomas joseph here and
today we are tackling a conundrum that
you all have asked about and that is
it's about puff pastry and today i'm
gonna share with you an easy hors
d'oeuvre that you can make for any
special occasion with puff pastry and a
few tricks and tips along the way for
success today we're making cheese straws
one of my favorite things they're a
really easy thing to make for unexpected
guests or even if you are planning a
party they're really great to have on
hand as a snack so to get started I have
some cheese in front of me what type of
cheese well today I'm using just
Parmesan cheese which you can find at
any supermarket now Parmesan cheese is
really great for a cheese straw because
it's really aged a lot of the moisture
over time has worked its way out of the
cheese so it makes it perfect for a
cheese straw because any excess moisture
in puff pastry is gonna create something
that's chewy and sometimes if it's under
baked it can be kind of soggy so using
ingredients that don't have a high
amount of moisture in them are really
key whatever you're making
whether it be savory like these cheese
straws today or if you're making
anything sweet so 1/4 of a cup like I
said an eighth of a teaspoon of cayenne
pepper and this is just to add a little
bit of spice to your G straws 1/2 a
teaspoon of ground mustard and this is
coleman's mustard an English brand of
mustard and it's really spicy and it has
this wonderful flavor if you haven't
tried dried mustard powder before I
would encourage you to pick up a jar of
it because it's so useful in so many
different recipes and then 1/4 teaspoon
of coarse kosher salts now we don't need
too much salt here because the parmesan
in and of itself has a good amount of
salinity to it so you don't have to add
too much salt to this recipe now I'm
just gonna whisk these ingredients
together and I'm gonna get my puff
pastry out of the refrigerator
so today I'm using regular store-bought
puff pastry and the great thing about
that is you can always have it on hand I
like to keep a package of store-bought
puff pastry in the freezer and the day
before I need it I've put it into the
refrigerator so that it defrost nice and
evenly it's the best way to defrost puff
pastry so that it doesn't split on you
or get soggy and usually puff pastry is
sold in you know fourteen ounce sizes
sometimes some brands go up to a pound
so really what you're looking for here
is just one package of puff pastry look
for a brand that uses all butter that
doesn't have any hydrogenated fats in it
because butter is really gonna give you
great flavor and it also gives you
really light and lofty cheese straws in
the end so I'm just dusting this with a
little bit of flour so it doesn't stick
to my work surface and depending on
which brand you buy it will come in
different shapes but I need a 12 by 16
inch rectangle to start so I'm just
short of that so I'm gonna take my
rolling pin here and roll this out a
little bit to a 12 by 16 inch rectangle
all right the next thing I need is an
egg wash and I have one large egg here
and a tablespoon of water and I'm just
gonna whisk this together the reason why
I added a little bit of water to this
egg is just to help it break up and so I
get a really light coat on my pastry
here I don't want anything that's too
thick and rich I just need something
that will help the cheese adhere to the
dough all right now using a pastry brush
a thin brush of the egg wash and you
want to go across the entire surface of
the dough and if you work quickly you
can pop these right into the oven so
make sure your oven is preheated to 400
degrees Fahrenheit now take your cheese
mixture and sprinkle it on half of the
dough and I'm working with the long side
towards me as you can see now if you
didn't want to use Parmesan cheese and
you wanted to use it
one type of cheese again just look for
an aged cheese any of those Alpine
cheese's that are aged are really great
and have a really fantastic flavor for a
cheese straw you could also use pecorino
you could use Grana Padano that would be
really fantastic in these cheese straws
here and now what I'm gonna do is take
the other side of the dough and fold it
on top creating a book almost and you
just want to press the dough down and
then give this a really gentle roll and
what this is gonna do is it's going to
make sure that all of that cheese is
firmly placed in between the layers of
the puff pastry so that when these bake
up in the oven none of the cheese comes
out it stays in your cheese straw all
right so now the fun part
we get to cut and twist the dough so I
like to use a ruler here and you're
gonna cut these into half-inch pieces
and I like to eyeball it
and you can really make these as
thinners thick as you'd like
these are gonna be nice kind of long and
thin cheese straws but if you want uh
something a little bit thicker maybe
shorter you could certainly do that it's
really up to you all right so now the
fun part we get to twist our cheese
straws so take two ends of your dough
and all you're gonna do right on your
sheet tray lined with parchment of
course is give the straws a good twist
and then what I like to do is I take the
two ends and you can use floured fingers
here push them down into the pan itself
this will help them keep a nice shape
and they won't kind of unfurl during the
baking process so what you want to do is
repeat the process with all of your
straws and if the dough gets too warm
you can pop these into the refrigerator
so that they chill up nicely before
baking but again they're going into that
400 degree oven so a really hot oven
that's important when you're making puff
pastry because what it does like pie
dough and biscuits it takes the layers
of cold butter and it puffs up in the
oven creates steam and that steam
creates wonderful leavening that gives
you light and delicate cheese straws so
these are going right into the oven all
right guys the cheese straws they've
been out of the oven and they've cooled
completely and look at how beautiful
they look
now if the dough is cold before you put
it in the oven they will retain their
shape like this but puff up nicely and
you'll get that wonderful kind of
swirly-twirly look to your cheese straws
they're just so amazing and they taste
just as good as they look I'm gonna use
this little end piece that I put in to
give it a try now as always if you have
any kitchen conundrums let us know
that's what we're here for to help you
out reach out to us with the hashtag

and as always guys click like and
